tennis-court: Tennis posts with net in the middle
Net dividing the court into two halves
Rectangular shape with marked boundary lines
tennis-racket: often has a logo or brand name on the strings or frame
string bed is strung with tension
interwoven strings forming a net within the frame
theodolite: telescope mounted on a rotating platform
level bubbles or a digital display
graduated horizontal and vertical circles (for measuring angles)
eyepiece for viewing through the telescope
toaster: heat or toasting elements inside the slots (occasionally visible)
crumb tray at the bottom (sometimes visible from certain angles)
typically made of metal or plastic
control knobs or buttons for adjusting browning settings
tomato: green leafy stem or calyx at the top
red, green, yellow, or orange color
tombstone: often found in a cemetery or graveyard setting
religious symbols (e.g., crosses, stars of David)
names, dates of birth, and death
top-hat: commonly black, but can also be seen in other colors
usually made from felt, silk, or wool
often has a ribbon or band around the base of the crown
touring-bike: front and rear racks for carrying panniers or bags
longer wheelbase for stability and comfort
sturdy frame, often with a larger and more robust build
drop handlebars for various hand positions
wider tires compared to standard road bikes
tower-pisa: located in an open area, often with greenery or other historic buildings nearby
the top-level has a belfry (bell chamber) with smaller arches
circular base and series of columns around each level
traffic-light: positioned at intersections or pedestrian crossings
vertical or horizontal pole or frame
treadmill: safety key or clip often attached to the panel
triceratops: often depicted in a prehistoric or natural landscape setting
large bony frill at the back of the head
four sturdy legs with hooved toes
tricycle: sometimes a basket or storage area at the back
sometimes colorful and designed for children
pedals typically located near the front wheel
trilobite-101: Segmented body with three distinct lobes (left pleural lobe, central axial lobe, right pleural lobe)
tripod: often made of metal, carbon fiber, or plastic
locking mechanisms on the legs or head
sometimes includes a handle or lever for adjusting the head
t-shirt: often has graphics, logos, or text on the front or back
generally loose-fitting and casual in style
comes in various colors and patterns
tuning-fork: a round handle or stem at the base of the fork
prongs often have a rounded end
two prongs (tines) extending parallel from a base
tweezer: arms connected at one end, creating a pincer-like mechanism
typically silver, black, or brightly colored
sometimes has a textured grip for better handling
umbrella-101: Handle at the bottom of the shaft (may be curved or straight)
Long, central shaft (often metal or wood)
Collapsible mechanism (may be manual or automatic)
Tip at the top of the shaft
Spokes or ribs extending from the shaft to support the canopy
unicorn: typically depicted in fantasy or mythical settings
a single, spiraled horn on its forehead
often surrounded by a magical or ethereal aura
often depicted with a flowing mane and tail
frequently depicted in white or other bright colors
vcr: buttons and controls on the front panel (e.g., play, stop, rewind)
LED or digital display panel showing time or status
input and output ports on the back (e.g., RCA connectors)
video-projector: lens or multiple lenses on the front
adjustable focus ring or buttons near the lens
control buttons or a small control panel on the top or sides
cooling vents or fans on the sides or back
washing-machine: a detergent drawer (often for front-loading machines)
water hoses or connections at the back
watch-101: A clasp or buckle to secure the strap/band
A strap or band that may be made of leather, metal, plastic, or fabric
Hour, minute, and possibly second hands
Buttons around the face/dial for additional functions (common in digital or multifunction watches)
A crown or dial on the side for adjusting time
waterfall: Flowing water descending vertically or nearly vertically
Movement blur of water captured in the photo
Mist or spray near the base of the falling water
A pool or basin of water at the bottom
A continuous cascade or series of cascades
watermelon: numerous black or white seeds embedded in the flesh (if cut open)
vibrant red or pink flesh (if cut open)
textured or smooth surface on the rind
welding-mask: sometimes has side windows for peripheral vision
wheelbarrow: two handles extending from the back
often used for carrying heavy loads
a pair of supporting legs at the rear
typically made of metal or plastic
usually found in construction sites, gardens, or farms
windmill: large, rotating blades or sails attached to a central hub
sometimes a small building or housing at the base
wine-bottle: dark green, brown, or clear color
filled with liquid, usually visible through the glass
cork, screw cap, or other closure at the top
xylophone: bars of varying lengths (longer bars produce lower pitches, shorter bars produce higher pitches)
often a frame or stand supporting the bars
bars arranged in a horizontal layout
resonator tubes beneath the bars (in some models)
a series of wooden or metal bars
yarmulke: can be knit, cloth, or suede
might be seen in religious or ceremonial contexts
typically worn on the crown of the head
may be worn by males, especially within Jewish communities
fits snugly without straps or ties
yo-yo: two round discs connected by an axle
can be a variety of colors
some models might have design patterns or logos on the discs
usually made of plastic, wood, or metal
may have a small knob or indentation in the center for gripping
zebra: long tail with a tuft of hair at the end
airplanes-101: a fuselage (the main body of the airplane)
one or more engines (jet engines or propellers)
car-side-101: Wheels and tires visible along the bottom
Side mirrors protruding near the front windows
greyhound: thin face with a long muzzle
small, folded ears (often referred to as "rose" ears)
toad: short legs relative to body size
colors ranging from brown, gray, olive, or tan
clutter: Presence of multiple, often unrelated objects
Limited visible surface area (such as floors or tables) due to the abundance of items
Lack of clear organization or arrangement
